data.title: suggest widget should not eat up End key
data.body:
Rant alert: I find the binding of End in the suggest widget very annoying and useless. IMHO:
* Likelihood I want to go to the end of line when pressing End: 99.95%.
* Likelihood I pressed End by accident: 0.04%.
* Likelihood I like to go to the last suggestion in the list: 0.01% (presumably the most useless of suggestions if our sorting is good).

I had to remove it today from my `keybindings.json` and I'm not sure why it's the default now.

data.title: Built-in Markdown Preview memory leak & slowdown
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 1607 (14393.1066)
- Memory: 11.75GB for system and applications, ~50% free

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open medium-sized Markdown file (>1000 lines, tens of kB of content)
2. Divide view to 2 columns, on right one click "Preview", close the right source (so you have: left column - Markdown source, right column - preview)
3. Edit, add sections - mostly write new content for around 20-30 minutes

Expected results: 
VSCode memory usage is stable, does not use more CPU with time.

Actual results:
After some time, VSCode process for Preview gets lots of memory (up to 1GB), updates of preview slow down and its process starts to use whole CPU core (25% on 4-core).
Closing the Preview kills the process with lots of memory and substantial CPU usage.
Sometimes it returns for a brief moment to the beginning of the file even though I'm editing at the end of it.

 Other parts of VSCode work as usual.

The file I'm editing does not have anything strange inside - few tens of headers, lots of text (mostly long lines) and lots of short formatting - it's documentation.

Screeenshot over time from process explorer - it took around 20 minutes of writing, to get from 50MB to 1GB, where it stays:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1816525/25002217/87614b24-2049-11e7-9079-9ec711faf5ee.png)

data.title: Completely broken Code
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->
Visual Studio completely broken
- VSCode Version: 1.11.1
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. No clue, but I think this might be severe enough to try and track down, I am ready to help investigating.

The last thing I remember doing is installing git history extension, not sure if it worked right after or not, left for the day, came today to the computer visual studio code is completely empty, black window, no command works except for dev tools (which show no console error whatsoever).

Tried restarting, uninstalling, removing extensions from the folder and more, to no avail.

data.title: Autocomplete across files
data.body:
I switched to VSC from Atom and one very useful feature I miss is autocomplete across opened documents. So for example, I have 3 files opened and in file 1 I have a variable called "thisIsExample". I switch to File 2 and start typing thisI... and VSC would auto-complete from the other file. 
This currently works, but the auto-compete, AFAIK only works within the opened file, but it is extremely useful when you can do this with all the opened files in the editor because if for example you have files that work together and use the same variables you dont have to switch to the other one just to check what you called it. In Atom this was possible.

data.title: preLaunchTask : looping
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.11.1 (d9484d12b38879b7f4cdd1150efeb2fd2c1fbf39, 2017-04-06T13:58:12.954Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.3.9600
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|mssql|ms-mssql|0.3.0|
|typescript-hero|rbbit|0.12.0|;

if preLaunchTask is configured will never stop to run the task configured.The debuuger try to start but the preLaunchTask configured it's restarted.
No matter which  task you run.


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. **set to package.json a script like** 
```json
"scripts": {
    "compile": "grunt build"
}
```
This grunt task is using grunt-copy  and grunt-ts to copy static resources and compile *.ts

2. **set  tasks.json like**
```json
{
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "command": "npm",
    "isShellCommand": true,
    "showOutput": "always",
    "suppressTaskName": true,
    "echoCommand": true,
    "tasks": [
        {
            "taskName":"compile",
            "args":["run","compile"]
        }
    ]
}
```
3. set the launch.json like
```json
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "type": "node",
            "request": "launch",
            "name": "Launch Program in DEVELOPMENT",
            "preLaunchTask": "**compile**",

            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/dist/main.js",
            "outFiles": ["${workspaceRoot}/dist/**/*.js"],
            "args":["env=development"]
        }
    ]
}
```

data.title: Limit Extension storage usage
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.1
- OS Version: Windows 7

There are so many index.db files that takes a lot of storage space
(for example: \AppData\Roaming\Code\User\workspaceStorage\13d502476c69532f0fce4f9ab9ea9f18\redhat.java\jdt_ws\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.jdt.core\index.db)

I know they are useful caches, but can we give it a limit space or give it a survival time or something else?

data.title: Closing tabs feels quite slow

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.1
- OS Version: macOS Sierra

One common workflow that I have is to close a bunch of tabs I have open by holding down ctrl-w. This very visibly and obviously lags the IDE. 

While the underlying problem may be very difficult, a simple solution seems to me that VSCode could instantly _show_ that the tab was closed, but continue to do the work necessary to close it in the background.

data.title: Python file key words highlight
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.1

I think these key words('in', 'not', 'and', 'or' ...) in a .py file should be highlighted in the default Dark+ theme, it would be better.

data.title: Typescript: Format creates line break in generics
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: Version 1.12.0-insider (1.12.0-insider)
- OS Version: macOS Sierra - 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a file with a class extending a generic class
2. Format the file


The problem I'm having is the super annoying formatting of classes extended with generic classes (It might occur in other instances as well). As seen in the screenshot it adds a line break after the first generic type property. 

I apologize if the issue should be reported somewhere else (js-beautify). But I'm not experiencing any problems when using it in Atom.

![screen shot 2017-04-13 at 10 46 36](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3367641/24997390/c494a486-2036-11e7-8074-609d6c8d7f08.png)

data.title: Include Copy Filename on the right-click menu
data.body: On right clicking a file tab title, It allows me to copy full path which is great. But having a way to copy file name alone will come handy. For example, I use both VSCode and Visual studio and ability to copy filename alone will help me find the file on VS quickly.

data.title: No Undo after Discard File Change
data.body:
**Error:**
---
After discarding changes, I can't undo to the previously edited file.

**Expected Behavior:**
---
After discarding changes, the user can Undo, in case it discarded by accident.

**Editor Information**
---
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.12.0-insider (a5e9d3b5e8e7e9a89dd6624a70aab031f189a6fa, 2017-04-11T06:05:26.421Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.5.0
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|ng-template|Angular|0.1.3|
|alignment|annsk|0.3.0|
|vscode-dash|deerawan|1.4.0|
|githistory|donjayamanne|0.2.0|
|gitlens|eamodio|3.4.5|
|tslint|eg2|0.12.0|
|sublime-keybindings|ms-vscode|2.0.1|;


---

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. Edit a File from a repository
2. Discard Using Command Pallete (cmd + shift + p, type discard changes, and select `Git: Discard Changes`)
3. Hit cmd + z or select Edit menu and click Undo

data.title: Is it possible to add tooltip hints for common *.conf.js?
data.body: Is it possible to add tooltip hints for common `*.conf.js` in a similar fashion it is done for `package.json` `tsconfig.json`, etc.? For example, `karma.conf.js`, `protractor.confg.js`, etc. I understand that it's not a regular json file, but such a capability would greatly help.

data.title: Open Code is a little slow
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.1 (1.11.1)
- OS Version: 10.12.4
- CPU: 2.2 GHz Intel Core i7
- Memory: 16GB

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open from command without any extension: open -n -b "com.microsoft.VSCode" --args --disable-extensions

I test for about ten times with a timer, the average time from open Code to editor finally shown is 2.5 seconds, I think it's unreasonable as an editor when both Sublime and MacVim take no more than 0.5 second.

I have also disabled the Welcome page

data.title: Git: Cannot read property 'fsPath' of undefined
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.1
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.4
- git: 2.9.2

Steps to Reproduce:

1. in `keybindings.json` I have:

```
{ "key": "alt+cmd+p", "command": "git.openChange", "when": "editorFocus" }
```
2. Make changes to an open file that's in git source control and save the file. Press `alt+cmd+p` and I get a notification with error:

```
Git: Cannot read property 'fsPath' of undefined
```

data.title: Editor: Arrow key doesn't work
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.11.1 (d9484d12b38879b7f4cdd1150efeb2fd2c1fbf39, 2017-04-06T13:55:56.395Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.51-40.58.amzn1.x86_64
- Extensions: none
---

Quite simple but serious problem.
Around version 1.11, editor window doesn't accept any arrow key at all!
I tried clean reinstall, however, it doesn't solve this symptom.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install Visual Studio Code
2. Open a file, type some characters, and press arrow keys to move around.

I'm using LXDE desktop on Ubuntu 16.
Special things are this environment is on TigerVNC virtual desktop prepared with Docker container version of Ubuntu.

$ lsb_release -a
No LSB modules are available.
Distributor ID:	Ubuntu
Description:	Ubuntu 16.04.2 LTS
Release:	16.04
Codename:	xenial
